results.title: Roland Robinson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Writers Talking”.
A poet with a strong attachment to the Australian landscape, Roland Robinson has a deep interest in Aboriginal lore, and performs his poetry with a memorable verve.

results.title: Bitter medicine = Medicina amara
results.creator_credit: Sabina Wynn, Jessica Douglas-Henry and Leichardt Women's Community Health Centre
results.brief_description: Bitter medicine explores the personal experiences of migrant women in Australia and their use of tranquillisers. Through a dramatised reconstruction the video explores reasons that compel women to seek help and the common medical response. This video suggests alternatives to medication and presents migrant women’s personal experiences and their determination to face a pill-free life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sabina Wynn, Jessica Douglas-Henry and Leichardt Women’s Community Health Centre

results.title: High and wild
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)
results.brief_description: High and Wild is the latest video from the Wilderness Society’s ongoing education program. It traces the journey of eight students and their teacher from Melbourne’s Kingswood College on what, for most, was their first wilderness experience. Shot on location in Victoria’s Wonnangatta-Moroka National Park “High and Wild” captures the students’ experience as they explore a variety of issues surrounding wilderness - such as alpine grazing logging, flora/fauna protection, outdoor recreation, Aboriginal and World Heritage values.

results.title: Bird safari in Australia
results.creator_credit: Jenny Erdos, Laszlo Erdos and David Cook
results.brief_description: Filmed entirely on location in the Mallee type country of Southern Australia, this film explores the paradise that is shared by birds, plants and insects in their natural environment. Features wonderful close-ups of undisturbed wildlife while the background music is a beautiful symphony of bird songs and calls. Narrated by Fred Parslow.

results.title: Work it out (Captioned)
results.brief_description: A video, aimed at young women between the ages of 14-20 years, that examines career opportunities available. The subject areas covered include : Women at Work; Careers Counselling; Equal Opportunity; Personal Development; Industrial relations; Social Studies.

results.title: Seen one, seen 'em all
results.brief_description: This program looks at media representation of ethnic and minority groups. The video uses a zany quiz show format to raise questions about ethnic stereotyping using examples from advertising. Both the video and its accompanying study guide provide a launching point for classroom discussion, activity and further study, suitable for a wide range of age groups.

results.title: The Consequences of nuclear war
results.creator_credit: Ross Christopher and Australian National University
results.brief_description: Highlights of a conference, with the same name as the title, which was held at the Australian National University. The papers dealt with various aspects of the nuclear arms race and were presented by a range of Australian and international speakers.

results.title: Right... from the start
results.creator_credit: John Julian, Queen Victoria Medical Centre and University of Melbourne
results.brief_description: This videotape is basically for training midwives and medical students and is about the principles of breastfeeding. Mothers are often subject to conflicting views and information about breastfeeding and this video tackles the problem.

results.title: Sprints
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Coaching and Training for Track and Field Events”.
Gives coaching tips for sprints events from Olympic athletes and coaches, plus footage of sprints events from the Moscow Olympics.

results.title: Compilation Ultimate skills
results.brief_description: Ultimate skills (Australia): Three motorcycle champions explain and demonstrate their skills at trail riding, motocross and road riding. 2.” Survival of the fastest” (U.K.): Shows the evolution of the motorcycle from a primitive machine into a glamorous, sophisticated piece of engineering. Looks at research and development and compares British and Japanese bikes.
